sense.name: a hidden problem or disadvantage
sense.examples: It seems too good to be true, so what's the catch? There was a catch to the offer, you had to listen to a marketing seminar for four hours in exchange for the free night in a hotel.

sense.name: an amount of fish caught
sense.examples: The fishing boat has a large container of ice to hold the catch. The fisherman shared his daily catch with a neighbor. The catches on these banks are not as big as they used to be decades ago.

sense.name: someone who is viewed as a highly desirable marriage partner
sense.examples: Mary thinks the young entrepreneur would be a hot catch. His friends thought John had quite the catch when he married a super model.

sense.name: a sudden break or crack in the voice
sense.examples: His voice had a catch in it when he spoke of his deceased brother. I got a catch in my throat when I swallowed a crumb the wrong way.

sense.name: artifact which is a restraint or stopper
sense.examples: The catch in the drain may be clogged. He used a phone book as a catch to keep the door from blowing closed.

sense.name: a latch or fastener, e.g., on a window or door
sense.examples: Be sure to secure the catch on the back gate so the dogs don't get out. The catch on the window was rusty and hard to move. The pearl necklace had a safety catch on it.

sense.name: a casual game of throwing a ball back and forth
sense.examples: Tom plays catch with his son in the evening up at the park.

sense.name: snatching or capturing a freely moving object
sense.examples: The outfielder made a tremendous catch at the wall to prevent a home run. Her catch at the rearing horse's bridle missed and he wheeled and ran off. The juggler's catch of burning torches was impressive.

sense.name: an apprehension or arrest by law enforcement
sense.examples: The news just reported the catch of the three escaped convicts. The credit for the catch of the burglar goes to the security guard on duty.
